newsitem.title: JAPAN: Yamaha develops new car suspension system.
newsitem.headline: Yamaha develops new car suspension system.

text.p: Yamaha Motor Co Ltd said on Thursday it has developed a new car suspension system intended to offer a more comfortable ride and greater handling stability at lower cost than computer-controlled systems.

The relative absorber system (REAS) consists of highly responsive right and left shock absorbers connected to each other by a shared hydraulic passage, with a third unit positioned at the mid-point of the passage between them.
The third unit consists of a valve, a gas-filled chamber and a free piston.

The new system will be cheaper than conventional computer-controlled suspension systems due to its simple structure, a Yamaha spokesman said. Computer-controlled suspension systems are used in luxury sedans.
Yamaha, the world's second-biggest motorcycle manufacturer, initially plans to sell the new system to Japanese carmakers, although the spokesman did not name any specific carmakers.
This is the first car suspension system sold by Yamaha, although it already manufactures and sells car engines.
Yamaha has applied for several patents in a number of countries on its suspension system, the spokesman said.
